Key Arguments: The bill is inconsistent with fundamental freedoms of speech and communication under international human rights instruments.
The bill poses a direct threat to the rights, safety, and wellbeing of Australians, as well as to democracy, society, and the economy.
The exclusion of government-authorised content from censorship is hypocritical and creates an asymmetry in rules.
The bill grants too much power to unelected bureaucrats, leading to potential silencing of speech without transparency or accountability.
The bill risks personal privacy by requiring digital platforms to provide information to the ACMA.
Notable Quotes: This bill is inconsistent with fundamental freedoms of speech and communication under international human rights instruments.
The exclusion of government-authorised content from this censorship is hypocritical and inconsistent.
This bill puts too much power in the hands of unelected bureaucrats silencing speech in the public square without transparency or accountability.
